summary: This document is a collection of email correspondence primarily from Richard C. Curtiss to various news organizations, government officials, and court clerks, seeking coverage for his claims about court corruption and the death of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes his personal theories about Epstein's death, allegations of government misconduct, and his attempts to get these stories published. The emails also contain responses from news editors and government offices declining his requests or providing procedural information.

persons.name: Richard C. Curtiss
persons.context: Individual sending emails to news organizations and government officials alleging widespread court corruption, sharing his experience inside the MCC where Epstein died, and requesting investigations into Epstein's death and government employee unions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Convicted sex offender whose death by hanging (ruled suicide) in the Metropolitan Correctional Center is a central topic of the correspondence, with Curtiss and others questioning the circumstances.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned by Jim W. Dean as potentially holding a 'final stash' of blackmail material related to Epstein and possibly negotiating a plea deal.

persons.name: Jim W. Dean
persons.context: News editor who corresponded with Curtiss, stating Epstein's jail story was too narrow/local for their coverage but sharing his view that Epstein's death was expected to prevent him from talking.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.role: US Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Mentioned by Curtiss as having sent him a Civilian Crime Report to fill out and return, indicating his attempts to report crimes to her office.

persons.name: David Schoen
persons.context: Attorney who met with Epstein in jail the day he died to discuss taking over his defense; he reportedly did not believe Epstein committed suicide based on their interaction.

persons.name: Barbara Sampson
persons.context: Ruled Epstein's death a suicide by hanging after review of investigative information and autopsy findings. Curtiss emailed her asking for drug test results.

persons.name: Aja Worthy-Davis
persons.context: Responded to Curtiss's inquiry from the NYC Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, confirming Epstein's death was ruled a suicide by hanging and directing media inquiries.

persons.name: Randolph T.
persons.role: Customer Care Advocate, The New York Times
persons.context: Responded to a customer care request, directing the reader to contact the news team for assistance with news-related inquiries.

persons.name: Adam Schiff
persons.context: One of the recipients of an email from Curtiss alleging government employee union organizing and crimes against him.

persons.name: Nancy Pelosi
persons.context: One of the recipients of an email from Curtiss alleging government employee union organizing and crimes against him.

persons.name: Jerrold Nadler
persons.context: One of the recipients of an email from Curtiss alleging government employee union organizing and crimes against him.

persons.name: Chuck Schumer
persons.context: Copied on an email from Curtiss to House members about government employee unions and alleged crimes.

persons.name: Keith Castaldo
persons.context: Copied on an email from Curtiss to House members about government employee unions and alleged crimes.

persons.name: Mike Pence
persons.context: Mentioned in a news excerpt within the correspondence regarding the firing of FBI Director James Comey.

persons.name: James Comey
persons.context: Mentioned in a news excerpt within the correspondence regarding his firing and the Russia investigation.

persons.name: Alexander Vindman
persons.context: Mentioned in a passage within the correspondence as being identified as the original source of the Ukraine Investigation, not the whistleblower.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as potentially holding blackmail material ('final stash') related to Epstein, possibly for plea negotiations.
Schoen met with Epstein in jail to discuss taking over his defense team on the day Epstein died.
Curtiss repeatedly emailed Dean, an editor, pitching news stories about court corruption and Epstein's death, with Dean declining.
Curtiss mentions receiving a Civilian Crime Report from US Attorney Strauss to fill out, indicating he reported crimes to her office.
Curtiss emailed Chief Medical Examiner Sampson directly to request drug test results from Epstein's autopsy.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by hanging (ruled a suicide) in the SHU section of the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York City.

events.title: OCME Confirms Suicide Ruling
events.description: The NYC Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, via Dr. Barbara Sampson, publicly ruled Epstein's death a suicide by hanging after review.

events.title: Correspondence on Epstein Death Theories
events.description: Email exchange where Jim W. Dean tells Richard Curtiss that Epstein's death was expected ('bumped off') to prevent him from talking, and mentions Maxwell's potential blackmail stash.

events.title: New York Times Customer Care Response
events.description: The New York Times Customer Care responds to a support request, directing the reader to contact the news team for news-related inquiries.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York City, NY (150 Park Row, New York, NY 10007)
8393 Pardee Hollow Road, Wayland, New York 14572
Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, 520 1st Avenue, New York, NY 10016
Federal Bureau of Prisons, 320 First Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20534
keyFacts: Richard C. Curtiss claims to have been inside the SHU (Special Housing Unit) of the Metropolitan Correctional Center where Jeffrey Epstein died and questions why guards turned cameras off and failed 30-minute checks.
Attorney David Schoen, who met with Epstein the day he died to discuss taking over his defense, stated he did not believe Epstein committed suicide based on their interaction that day.

Editor Jim W. Dean expressed the view that Epstein's death in jail was expected ('bumped off') to prevent him from talking, and suggested Ghislaine Maxwell may hold a 'final stash' of blackmail material.
The NYC Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Barbara Sampson, officially ruled Epstein's death a suicide by hanging after reviewing all investigative information and autopsy findings.
The correspondence includes allegations by Curtiss of widespread corruption involving government employees, court employees, and judges forging documents and signatures.
